alternatives.transcript: Hi, I'm Jacques Pepin and I'm cooking at home. We call it pissenlit in France, down the lion, you know, lion teeth. And this is really a right of spring for us in the summer. I want to show you how to handle it. First, I'm going to put some bacon or pancetta. I want to do a pretty strong sauce. Here I'm doing it for 2, 3 people. I have 3 slices of bacon. So, And I put a dash of olive oil on top because I will put the olive oil in the dressing. And I want to cook that until it's nice and brown. Now here is, they come out of the ground. Usually, you don't pick them up when the flowers are there. The flowers is what they do, you know, Italian do, don't lie on wine and that with the flower or the bud. But this 1 is small enough so basically you want to go deep enough into the ground to get the root here because the root it was nice and white as deep as you can go into the ground here and often I split it in half as you can see this 1 here, it's a bit bigger. So I have a nice bottom here. Cut the black, clean up around. Maybe I cut it in half, separate it. Oh, I have a bad leaf here. And that's it. This has to be washed 2, 3 times. You know, I wash it. When I do it, I let it soak in water, you know, water out of the tap. I have about 2, 3 cups here. And of course, after it's washed, I put them into the machine so that I really take the water out of it. So here, you can see this is cooking nicely here. I have bread in the oven also because we have croutons with that and I have eggs. So when I do that for me, it's basically a whole meal. So here, we'll start with the garlic. Crush the garlic here. Well, maybe another little piece. ♪♪ In Lyon, where I come from, down lion is very big in summer. That's where I say we call it pissant li, P-I-S-S-E-N-T-I-L. And often we do that with a smoked herring. So here, for 2 or 3, I have a good teaspoon, teaspoon and a half of garlic. I put anchovy paste or a couple of anchovy that you crush and put that. So here I will put like, I would say, 2 good teaspoon of anchovy paste, salt, of course, pepper, a dash of vinegar. Yeah, not much, like a teaspoon of vinegar, you know? That will be the base of my mixture. And of course, the oil that I have here and the fat from the bacon, that's going to go in the dressing as well. That's a lot of olive oil. So, that's kind of ready. And I have my crouton right out of the oven. When I do crouton like this, I cut bread, like coarse bread like this. And I sprinkle a little bit of oil on top and put it into the oven. You know, that's 1 of the best way of doing it. So here is the rest of my dressing. So we'll mix it here. Remember the anchovy paste, you have to crush it a little bit. Sometimes, you know, I only put the fat of the bacon here and keep the bacon to sprinkle on top. I could have done there. I forgot. And here I have my dandelion here. What I say when I do that, it's basically a whole meal for me. So we mix this. My father was very big down lion. I learned with him when I was a kid. You are a rest in spring. You have to eat down at least 3, 4 times to clean your blood. I was cleaning your blood. Okay, highly seasoned. And I will serve that into a plate like this. A big, yeah, a big portion. I love the bacon. I like to put the bacon on top. Here it is. And then the croutons are going to go there. And finally, the eggs. And those eggs are cooked 7 minutes. Drop them in boiling water, bring back to a boil, 7 minutes, and then I cool them up too. So as you can see, they are still just slightly wet in the center. And this is right the taste of my youth. Don't lie on salad in the spring with the croutons, the eggs and so forth. Happy cooking.

paragraphs.transcript:
Hi, I'm Jacques Pepin and I'm cooking at home. We call it pissenlit in France, down the lion, you know, lion teeth. And this is really a right of spring for us in the summer. I want to show you how to handle it. First, I'm going to put some bacon or pancetta.

I want to do a pretty strong sauce. Here I'm doing it for 2, 3 people. I have 3 slices of bacon. So, And I put a dash of olive oil on top because I will put the olive oil in the dressing. And I want to cook that until it's nice and brown.

Now here is, they come out of the ground. Usually, you don't pick them up when the flowers are there. The flowers is what they do, you know, Italian do, don't lie on wine and that with the flower or the bud. But this 1 is small enough so basically you want to go deep enough into the ground to get the root here because the root it was nice and white as deep as you can go into the ground here and often I split it in half as you can see this 1 here, it's a bit bigger. So I have a nice bottom here.

Cut the black, clean up around. Maybe I cut it in half, separate it. Oh, I have a bad leaf here. And that's it. This has to be washed 2, 3 times.

You know, I wash it. When I do it, I let it soak in water, you know, water out of the tap. I have about 2, 3 cups here. And of course, after it's washed, I put them into the machine so that I really take the water out of it. So here, you can see this is cooking nicely here.

I have bread in the oven also because we have croutons with that and I have eggs. So when I do that for me, it's basically a whole meal. So here, we'll start with the garlic. Crush the garlic here. Well, maybe another little piece.

♪♪ In Lyon, where I come from, down lion is very big in summer. That's where I say we call it pissant li, P-I-S-S-E-N-T-I-L. And often we do that with a smoked herring. So here, for 2 or 3, I have a good teaspoon, teaspoon and a half of garlic. I put anchovy paste or a couple of anchovy that you crush and put that.

So here I will put like, I would say, 2 good teaspoon of anchovy paste, salt, of course, pepper, a dash of vinegar. Yeah, not much, like a teaspoon of vinegar, you know? That will be the base of my mixture. And of course, the oil that I have here and the fat from the bacon, that's going to go in the dressing as well. That's a lot of olive oil.

So, that's kind of ready. And I have my crouton right out of the oven. When I do crouton like this, I cut bread, like coarse bread like this. And I sprinkle a little bit of oil on top and put it into the oven. You know, that's 1 of the best way of doing it.

So here is the rest of my dressing. So we'll mix it here. Remember the anchovy paste, you have to crush it a little bit. Sometimes, you know, I only put the fat of the bacon here and keep the bacon to sprinkle on top. I could have done there.

I forgot. And here I have my dandelion here. What I say when I do that, it's basically a whole meal for me. So we mix this. My father was very big down lion.

I learned with him when I was a kid. You are a rest in spring. You have to eat down at least 3, 4 times to clean your blood. I was cleaning your blood. Okay, highly seasoned.

And I will serve that into a plate like this. A big, yeah, a big portion. I love the bacon. I like to put the bacon on top. Here it is.

And then the croutons are going to go there. And finally, the eggs. And those eggs are cooked 7 minutes. Drop them in boiling water, bring back to a boil, 7 minutes, and then I cool them up too. So as you can see, they are still just slightly wet in the center.

And this is right the taste of my youth. Don't lie on salad in the spring with the croutons, the eggs and so forth. Happy cooking.

sentences.text: Hi, I'm Jacques Pepin and I'm cooking at home.
We call it pissenlit in France, down the lion, you know, lion teeth.
And this is really a right of spring for us in the summer.
I want to show you how to handle it.
First, I'm going to put some bacon or pancetta.
I want to do a pretty strong sauce.
Here I'm doing it for 2, 3 people.
I have 3 slices of bacon.
So, And I put a dash of olive oil on top because I will put the olive oil in the dressing.
And I want to cook that until it's nice and brown.
Now here is, they come out of the ground.
Usually, you don't pick them up when the flowers are there.
The flowers is what they do, you know, Italian do, don't lie on wine and that with the flower or the bud.

But this 1 is small enough so basically you want to go deep enough into the ground to get the root here because the root it was nice and white as deep as you can go into the ground here and often I split it in half as you can see this 1 here, it's a bit bigger.
So I have a nice bottom here.
Cut the black, clean up around.
Maybe I cut it in half, separate it.
Oh, I have a bad leaf here.
And that's it.
This has to be washed 2, 3 times.
You know, I wash it.
When I do it, I let it soak in water, you know, water out of the tap.
I have about 2, 3 cups here.
And of course, after it's washed, I put them into the machine so that I really take the water out of it.
So here, you can see this is cooking nicely here.
I have bread in the oven also because we have croutons with that and I have eggs.
So when I do that for me, it's basically a whole meal.
So here, we'll start with the garlic.
Crush the garlic here.
Well, maybe another little piece.
♪♪ In Lyon, where I come from, down lion is very big in summer.
That's where I say we call it pissant li, P-I-S-S-E-N-T-I-L.
And often we do that with a smoked herring.
So here, for 2 or 3, I have a good teaspoon, teaspoon and a half of garlic.
I put anchovy paste or a couple of anchovy that you crush and put that.
So here I will put like, I would say, 2 good teaspoon of anchovy paste, salt, of course, pepper, a dash of vinegar.
Yeah, not much, like a teaspoon of vinegar, you know?
That will be the base of my mixture.
And of course, the oil that I have here and the fat from the bacon, that's going to go in the dressing as well.
That's a lot of olive oil.
So, that's kind of ready.
And I have my crouton right out of the oven.
When I do crouton like this, I cut bread, like coarse bread like this.
And I sprinkle a little bit of oil on top and put it into the oven.
You know, that's 1 of the best way of doing it.
So here is the rest of my dressing.
So we'll mix it here.
Remember the anchovy paste, you have to crush it a little bit.
Sometimes, you know, I only put the fat of the bacon here and keep the bacon to sprinkle on top.
I could have done there.
I forgot.
And here I have my dandelion here.
What I say when I do that, it's basically a whole meal for me.
So we mix this.
My father was very big down lion.
I learned with him when I was a kid.
You are a rest in spring.
You have to eat down at least 3, 4 times to clean your blood.
I was cleaning your blood.
Okay, highly seasoned.
And I will serve that into a plate like this.
A big, yeah, a big portion.
I love the bacon.
I like to put the bacon on top.
Here it is.
And then the croutons are going to go there.
And finally, the eggs.
And those eggs are cooked 7 minutes.
Drop them in boiling water, bring back to a boil, 7 minutes, and then I cool them up too.
So as you can see, they are still just slightly wet in the center.
And this is right the taste of my youth.
Don't lie on salad in the spring with the croutons, the eggs and so forth.
Happy cooking.
